commentBody:
Rebuses!  
Luckily, these are the harmless variety.
They will not squish you.

The pictorial clues were cute, and not stress inducing.  But what won me over were some of the fine entries, e.g. HUMDINGERS, ESPIAL, and NOISOME (one of my all time favorite words). A very pleasing Wednesday.

I also got a kick out of the reference to COMMODORE computers.  We had a Commodore 64 back in the day, although I mostly used it to play Radar Rat Race.

My.  My. My. 

Wasn‚Äôt that some tasty granola?

I liked the symbol clues, those were very well done.

A lot of the clues today felt more like obscure vocabulary quiz.  HUMDINGERS, NOISOME, ESPIAL, DINS, MOCHI, and they all seemed to cross each other and cross other awkward or proper name trivia clues like GAH, IRENE, EHOW, BERNARDO, ASSES as an answer for "Nincompoops", somehow knowing the name of the city Iowa State is in.

Other than the theme clues, I was not a fan of today's puzzle.

üíØ‚≠êÔ∏èü•á

PICTURE PERFECT

Or, practicing up for my eye doctor appointment!

With Deb's permission, I shake my fist at the sky over ESPIAL.

I can't argue against it being valid, but I can certainly choose to give it an üôÑ, some üòí, and a bit of üò†

Emus at my first post, trying again.

Good puzzle, though I had to run the alphabet for the K in ARK/KESHA.

Terrence Howard believes he's discovered 1x1 = 2.  

That's right.

Newton missed that.  So did Kepler and Hubble.  Einstein and Bohr.  NASA and the Royal Society never realized that if someone gives you 1 dollar 1 time, then you have two dollars.

I could have done without 42D.

Are 40d/49a dialectal? They aren't homophones when I say them.
I wouldn't know that EHOW existed if it wasn't for its frequent appearance in the NYT crossword, so just how much of a "popular website" is it really?
Very tasty indeed. I liked the picture clues and the unusual entries (ESPIAL, ARAM, SAMUS, etc.), most of which I did not know but discovered. Great fun!
ESPIEL? Methinks on a Wednesday puzzle when thou useth archaic English, thou shalt indicate so in thy clue.

Emoji rebuses! My kind of puzzle. I finished this just under my average solve time. I liked the theme entries as well as some of the more obscure fill. I enjoy learning something new from the puzzle and I learned several new words today. Thank you, Vincent. This one was a HUMDINGER for sure!!
So. Many. Proper. Nouns.

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
Transported me back to the ASL picto-puzzle from when I first started solving.

Very dense Wednesday and all the nicer for it.

Hoo boy, that was a doozy! Loved seeing the emojis and figuring out the answers. COMMODORES were a blast from the past. I loved the ‚ÄúNoted wildlife refuge‚Äù, too. 

But ESPIAL, srsly?

Harder than Friday or Saturday, methinks. 

Never heard of a pip outside of Gladys knight or dice. 

Noisome and espial are new to me. And my phone autocorrect, as well. 

But great puzzle. I enjoyed this Wednesday. Thank you
Best Wednesday in literal years. First one up to the standard of what the puzzle was before the revenue push that I can remember in a long time

Ugh. I had no issue with the little picture clues.  But espial and noisome were both well beyond my ken.

Apparently they are real words though.  Looking at NGram Viewer, noisome significantly outpaces "odiferous", whick makes no sense to me at all.  The latter is a word that people use.  I have to assume that a majority just thought noisome means noisy?

At least it accurately reports the observation that no one has ever actually used espial.  :)

Anyway, while certainly solvable this did not seem like a Wednesday at all.  Difficulty is really all over the map at the Times lately.  :(

And yep, XWStwats reports "Very Hard".  There's a problem here, because several Friday/Saturday puzzles have been trivially easy.  It's not fair to outline a weekly progression policy and then completely ignore it.

What a weird puzzle.

In the end I completed it quite quickly, but I had to look up the crossing of F_CA and _R_NE. The second blank in the second entry came from _UM[D]I_G_RS - there the [D] was a guess. Once I looked up FICA, IRENE became the obvious solution, which in turn led to my recalling HUMDINGERS (I've seen it here once before), even though I couldn't remember what it meant and how "Pips" was a clue for it - I needed the column and an internet search to get that. Not knowing NOISOME for "offensively odorous" didn't help. 

The theme was OK even if it didn't particularly grab me.

The misdirection in many of the clues was quite nice to see.

It's just a (personal) pity my ultimate struggles were caused not by clever clueing but rather by my being unfamiliar with a few entries. It's on me, of course, but it still doesn't feel great.
Gah!
I have a real pip of a cat, named Pip! She often sits with me while I do crosswords and I enjoy telling her ‚ÄúPip! You‚Äôre adorable! You made the Times puzzle again!‚Äù

commentBody:
I fear that Sam's explanation of HUMDINGER is incomplete. The word applies not only to people, but even more to things or events of exceptional or surprising quality. So, this was a HUMDINGER of a puzzle.  And last year's World Series was a 'pip' of a sports event.

Best wishes for all to whom this new moon is the start of something!

Not the most enjoyable grid today. The fill was clearly stretched to the limits (I think I've seen ESPIAL once in my life outside classic literature or a crossword). The theme unfortunately didn't make up for it.

Ooooh - after yesterday's triumph, today was tough. No, not 'noisome', I knew that. I didn't know any of the proper names, which seem very obscure to me. 

HUT? If you say so.

GAS UP somehow sounds nasty to me, but is not. SASS again! And the same meaning as fresh, another new one for me.

I've not heard of farfalle being called bow-ties, or macaroni called elbows, except in the crossword, is it everyday use?
Definitely harder than last Saturday. This is the level of difficulty I want.

This is no "The woods are lovely, dark, and deep..." kind of snow we are having, glory be, in northern Minnesota this Tuesday night/Wednesday morning.

A blizzard just like from Hollywood.

The wind is rattling the windows, and the streetlight shows bands of snow mostly moving horizontally, except when there's a burst of wind and then they'll fly in too many directions to keep track of.

I feel really lucky.
I had to look up NOISOME as meaning odorous. I would have thought it had something to do with.....noise? But it checked out! :)
One of the hardest in recent memory.

‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs FICA and why is he getting all my money?‚Äù

A classic line that I‚Äôm sure many of us thought of when looking at our first paycheck. 

Fun puzzle. I definitely had some brain farts but somehow managed to find my way through. I looked back at the 02/09/2020 puzzle that was mentioned in the constructor notes, and sure enough, I had slammed through that. Have no memory of it.

It seems my comment was emu‚Äôd, even though I prepared for a questionable word quote from the puzzle by inserting an asterisk for one of its letters. I‚Äôm sure it will show up around 11am, but in the meantime‚Ä¶

Can we please get a ruling that if a word is acceptable for the puzzle, it‚Äôs acceptable for the comment section as well? The emu filters are baffling, and annoyingly puritanical.
Yowzers, that was tough.
Hard, yes, but didn't enjoy the thesaurus clues.
Wow, that was a HUMDINGER!
Per the guard in Hamlet. "something is noisome in the state of Denmark." Difficult Wednesday puzzle but still enjoyable. Perhaps there needs to be a "themed" Friday puzzle day.
Is it just me? Or, are Wednesday puzzles becoming more like Thursday puzzles?

I didn't know that a "pip" was anything but a seed. I never saw "Fame," "Hustle and Flow," or "High School Musical." I think I encountered "gas up" once in a previous NYT puzzle, but never in the wild.  I didn't know the singer or the song. I had "noxious" initially instead of NOISOME. For "X" I initially had the Greek letter rather than the Roman numeral. I don't use emojis...I can see the point of them when they help make clear the intent of something that might be misinterpreted otherwise, but otherwise they seem like something a girl in middle school would fall back on, so I use words instead.

I struggled, I backed off and redid answers quite a bit, I finished with one of my slowest times ever for a Wednesday, but I didn't look up a thing, so I'm not complaining.

While I found the theme enjoyable, the rest of the puzzle was very obscure in its language. Overall, too difficult for a Wednesday. This seems more suited to a Thursday at the earliest. Having to break out the thesaurus for multiple clues just isn‚Äôt how I want to spend my Wednesday mornings.

So, my brain loves hills to climb in puzzles, loves rub.  Give me answers out of my wheelhouse, words that have never entered my ears, riddles to crack, and my brain says, ‚ÄúLet me at it!‚Äù

So, there was that going on for me today, a brain-happifying puzzle.

Also, happifying was this theme.  Using strings of emojis for theme clues has been done before, but not often, and not like it was done today.  Bravo!

Smiles came as well from a couple of clue echoes.  [Write ‚Äútheir‚Äù for ‚Äúthere"] for ERR echoes a clue from two weeks ago ‚Äì [Mistake ‚Äúair‚Äù for ‚ÄúHeir‚Äù, say], where rhymes to ERR are featured in the clues.

Also, [Pips], the clue for HUMDINGERS, recalls Victor‚Äôs last NYT puzzle, where dice were depicted in the grid, and the letter O represented the pips.

And I must say that HUMDINGERS after Sunday‚Äôs SMITHEREENS has once again smitten me over our quirky language.

The box, therefore, was filled with mood-lifting pings for me, Victor, making for one splendid outing.  Thank you!

The last time NOISOME and ESPIAL were seen this close together, they were hand-in-hand watching the ARK float away. The ark itself, incidentally, making for a pretty noisome espial if you espied from inside, I‚Äôd bet.

This puzzle had a few signs of some earlier Times.
Merely a symbolic gesture?

hmmm...

A theorem:

struggle X amount of struggle = level of nastiness?

No matter how long I've been doing these puzzles, I STILL cannot understand how people get mad and nasty about PUZZLES.

Besides, Wednesdays are those puzzle days when there is a range of difficulty. This one was near the top of the range for a Wednesday. And I like a challenge.

There was no cheap fill (as people ALWAYS complain about) after the puzzle theme was sussed out.

FUN and CHALLENGING!

I'll admit to having been a little cranky while solving: "Why do we need emoji clues that are so brainlessly guessable?"  But all was forgiven on my last fill, the K in ARK for [Noted wildlife refuge.] which elicited the Ha!

Emus ate my comment.

Short version.

Loved it.

On a Sunday evening in the spring of 1966, Godzilla and Mothra set a side their differences for a while, and tune into American TV: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nl-i4Y8s0U8&list=RDnl-i4Y8s0U8&start_radio=1 ("Hey Moth, pass the mochi!") IYKYK *** Yesterday evening, I was delighted to find that my phone had two emojis for horses, four for fireworks, and one for a little red and gold money envelope: Health and Happiness, Peace and Prosperity to all my fellow Word-players in the Year of the Horse!

Whew. Typical tough Wednesday workout for me. None of the theme answers were going to dawn on me from the clues but managed to work them all out from the crosses. A couple of things I wasn't a big fan of, but ended up being an enjoyable solve for the most part. And, of course a puzzle find. A Thursday from June 3, 1999 by Frances Hansen. Three 15 letter across theme answers: "Cuckoo" UTTERLYDEMENTED "Grouse" GRUMBLEANDGRIPE "Gull" DUPETHETRUSTING And then a 15 letter reveal down the very middle of the puzzle: "Clues for 20-, 39- and 56-across?" BIRDSOFAFEATHER Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=6/3/1999&g=7&d=D I'm done. ....

Today we have people complaining that this puzzle was "too hard" for a Wednesday. One of them says they don't want to spend Wednesday morning that way. Which begs the question: Why are you spending your morning that way if you hate it? Stick to Monday where you'll be safe from the dreaded thesaurus.

Ten Wednesdays in a row with no lookups! I was a few minutes over my average today, and I nearly gave up, but I finally removed the ‚Äún‚Äù I had at the end of ESPIAL (it was a guess!) and things started to click. NOISOME, HUMDINGERS, and MOTHRA about did me in, but I fought back! Great puzzle!
I was surprised at ROOFS thinking it must be some Americanisation. I've since been down the rabbit hole and apparently rooves is considered archaic!

I like words. That's why I like crossword puzzles. I don't like pictures that stand for words. If I did, I'd search for online showings of the old TV show Concentration. Not quite equivalent, but, hey, same kind of pictures. Having said that, it turned out to be a really easy puzzle for me, despite some ancient entries and some unknows that were easily gleaned from the crosses. It helped that the theme answers were pretty simple to figure out after just a few letters.

Of course I had Noxious before NOISOME, but since I did know that it meant foul-smelling, likely from previous puzzles, I was quickly able to substitute it.

Alas, this one did not float my boat. I mean, my ARK.

Not much to say about this puzzle today. The theme was just ok, not really my favorite. The puzzle did have a lot of proper nouns and less common words, but I knew most of them or could get quickly from crossing so not hard for me at all. I liked the HUMDINGERS clue and have some nostalgia for the COMMODORES ( both the computers and Lionel Richie‚Äôs band). But honestly don‚Äôt have much else to add today, or, in the words of Forrest Gump, which I just rewatched, ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs all I have to say about that.‚Äù

[Twerking]













A BUN DANCE

That was an enjoyable Wednesday.

Wasn't there an RANDB group called Gladys Knight and the Humdingers? They had a song about a train but exactly which train and where it was going I can't recall.

No clue if yesterday's Comment was ever released, but since there hasn't been a rebellion or a mass population shift, I guess not.  Oh well.
I knew for a certainty that this is NOT THURSDAY, so I'm figuring (post-solve) that this just wasn't hard enough (plus lacked at least one more Themer) ...so that it landed on Wednesday.  
I did like this well enough ...but Japanese demon and "Fame" and Nintendo...woof!  All out of my wheelhouse.  Thank goodness for the Crosses.

Signs that one is No Longer Young:  worked on the fund-raiser, made supper, crashed and went to bed at 7:30....and didn't wake up until 4:30!!  Apparently I didn't even roll over.  LOL

The P in ESPIAL was the last one to fall for me. My spell check doesn't think ESPIAL is a word, and just this once I have to agree. (I know it's in the dictionary, Barry, don't bother.)

Otherwise, it was a fun puzzle! It reminds me of a weird little book called FIGURES OF SPEECH, by Mervyn Peake, better known as the author of the Gormenghast novels. He had illustrated a bunch of figures of speech, and you're supposed to suss out what they are. It's a fun way to kill a few minutes. Gormenghast, on the other hand, is a doorstop-sized fever dream. Highly recommended.
Excellent crossword! Only improvement would have been to replace the graphical clues with words.
Very clever! A truly great puzzle. Bravo!!!

Loved this puzzle! Noisome is a new fave. 
Thanks to the constructor for this toothsome Wednesday.

Dear NYT Puzzle Dept:

I know you don't personally print the puzzle in the physical paper or set the type or choose the font or do anything that affects how the puzzle will actually appear to someone who subscribes  to the dead tree edition.  But may I remind you that it is home subscribers who are keeping the NYT afloat and most likely paying your salaries.  

So that if you have a puzzle with visual clues that cannot be made out by people solving in the physical paper, it doesn't matter how clearly they may appear online.  

Please grab yourself a copy of today's Times.  Go to the puzzle page and tell me if you have the slightest clue as to what clue 39A  is depicting.  You say that you already know?  OK -- give the paper to your mother or your sister or your best friend and challenge them to tell you what on earth clue 39A is supposed to be.

I rest my case.  Except I don't -- not really.  After all, it's not only on the puzzle page that the NYT's complete lack of concern for the subscriber to the physical paper is manifested.  Blurry, fuzzy, very pale, and even completely missing print is everywhere these days.  It would not have gone out that way perhaps as little as five years ago.
ERE and ERR are only homophones if you mispronounce the later (though admittedly the language is definitely shifting in that direction and nothing matters anymore so have at it)

I appreciate the theme and some of the longer clues but this was a rough one. ESPIAL, NOISOME, EHOW (this is not a popular website, contrary to the clue), the awkward plural of PASTAS, SAMUS, ARAM. It was just unpleasant, sorry.

I thought the theme was very witty.

And I enjoyed the not-so-common vocabulary words. More please.

"Yes, you're once, twice, three times a pc
 And I love you"

I was just doing some of the Saturdays in the archive that I hadn't done yet, and was excited to go back to an easier Wednesday once it came out. Didn't happen lol, this almost feels like another Saturday!

I convinced myself X was TEd, as in TED-X, and EATEd was an archaic form.  And tESHA was a singer, so strongly that I concluded ARt was an Artic Reindeer trail or something.   

It‚Äôs what I know to be true that really isn‚Äôt that gets me these days.

Lucked out on ARAM from the language ARAMaic.

This one felt slow but I was actually 2.0% faster than my Wednesday average according to XWSTATS. I'm still looking for that elusive day when I match my average EXACTLY (without looking up the time to match in advance). I liked the picture clues -- a nice twist. Keep mixing it up, NYT!
Fun solve! Loved the theme, and I learned a couple of new words and a new meaning for the word pips. As a chicken keeper, I first had "hatched out" for that one. Well done!

I am finding 1/6 of the puzzle impenetrable -- the middle part of the western half.  Timewise, I am already 58% over average.  I hope to return here victorious, but I have my doubts.  I am curious if it is just me, or others are having (or had) the same experience.  I will read the rest of the comments when I've finished one way or the other.

I learned a few words from today's crossword so thank you for that, constructor! 

I also found the clue "big name in water filters" so comically boring I laughed out loud. ü´£üòÑ

espial??

happy wednesday, everyone!

Might have been the hardest Wednesday in years! When I finished I felt for sure espial was going to be wrong (took me three times to type that just now, Apple spellcheck does not even like that word!).
Gold medal for a Wednesday!
ESPIAL is terribad, really taking the shine off an otherwise enjoyable puzzle. And this is from someone who isn‚Äôt a fan of pictorial clues.

Dense in all the wrong ways, unfortunately. I really wanted this puzzle to succeed but it insisted upon itself through trivia, proper noun naticks, and intentionally obtuse word choices. I think other than those cases, the puzzle was a fun one, and I actually appreciated the difficulty when it felt earned.

Loved the clues for ARK, ERR/ERE. 
I would take RNB over RANDB.

Nice challenge for a Wednesday. "Bennie and the Jets" played in my head; enough to jog my memory of who led the Sharks. The emoji clues weren't too tricky. But when I saw X, I wondered "Who's X? And Y?"

I've never seen "West Side Story," but I know the music, and some of the characters. BERNARDO was not one of those, but easy enough with the crosses. NOISOME was great, but miasmic and stygian also fit, and are also interesting words.

Humdinger is great word I first came  across in a song from Bob Dylan's Freewheeling" album, rhymed with Folksinger, describing a girlfriend that I always thought might have been Joan Baez.

Humdinger - Folksinger was also - I believe, the name of a compilation album set of Dylan's early recordings.
Saturday already is it?

I see lots of comments about how difficult this puzzle was. I guess I was just on the constructors wavelength this time, because I finished in less than 3/4 of my Wednesday average, sespite trying 'TSA agents', before SORCERERS and 'ETSY' before EHOW. 

My last to fall was the crossing of R AND B with BERNARDO. The name wouldn't come to me, and it took me a long time to parse RAND_ as two words.

(It probably helped that I'm familiar with the meaning of the word NOISESOME).

Lots of Japanese horror in today's puzzle. I happen to have watched Kwaidan a few days ago, an anthology of four Japanese horror vignettes. It was excellent and if you have not seen it, put it on your cinema bucket list. There were no ONI or Gojira or Mothra, but my favorite story of the four was The Woman of the Snow," which featured a yuki-onna ("snow woman") played by the lovely Keiko Kishi. She first caught my eye in Yasujir≈ç Ozu's "Early Spring" -- also worth a watch. He portrayal of the yuki-onna was a master class in portraying a cold, heartless (almost??) beautiful woman. https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kwaidan_(film)
That bottom third was a mess...
Who ever complained about last week definitely won't be complaining today lol.  This was a doozy
Absolutely thrilled to see my queen Mothra show up this morning!

Another couple of clues that I'm on my way out. It took me over 29 minutes to finish this one even using Autocheck, and I might have beat that 29 minutes a bit if I hadn't had to run the alphabet on HUMD_NGERS of all things!

Barry A...please don't call me out üòâ.

I came over to write a comment solely for ESPIAL. I don't think it's unfair, I'm sure it's a real word, and it's comprehensible enough if you're familiar with its root word. But nonetheless‚Äîthat's a mean, mean answer.

E-(roughly rhymes with aisle)?

In the past 18 months we‚Äôve had ENISLE, ENSILE, and today ESPIAL.

I‚Äôm going to enfile* these away for future reference.

*which is archaic for ‚Äúthread onto a cord or string‚Äù, so think bracelet, not database.
Theme was good. But the rest of the fill was very very bad. Disappointing.

Late puzzle find. A Wednesday from May 4, 2011 by Jeff Chen. All of theme answers were down answers. One appropriate clue and answer was: "Jocular term for fear of palindromes" AIBOHPHOBIA Except... that was a down answer and what actually appeared was AIBOHP. The ending letter appeared in a block that had no crosses. All the other theme answers were also downs, and the ending letter appeared the same way: ABLEWASIER ROTA DEIF MADAMI Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/4/2011&g=7&d=D .....

GAH! So many don't-knows for me in this HUMDINGER. I had more empty squares throughout than on a typical Saturday! Luckily my millennialness gave me EFRON, TERRENCE, and KESHA as a foothold, and I encountered NOISOME the other day in the archives, but much of the top half eluded me. I thought the theme was cute and well-executed. I can't complain about a solid challenge in the middle of the week.
what an unenjoyable waste of 20 minutes. noisome? espial? really? I get wordplay but this was a reach.

pip: one extraordinary of its kind

@Steve L R and L are called "liquid consonants." They effect the vowel sounds around them. Vowels sounds in these environments are hard to pin down. Their pronunciation varies a lot from speaker to speaker, I guess. From Google: "Liquid consonants in English are the approximant sounds /l/ and /r/, which are produced with minimal obstruction to the airflow, allowing them to function smoothly like vowels. As part of the sonorant class, these sounds are voiced, sustained, and often appear in consonant clusters (e.g., "fly", "try"). They are categorized into lateral (l) and retroflex/rhotic (r) types." Also: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liquid_consonant
